title: Effect of Mutations to the FXN Gene

content.question: Read each question carefully. Write your response in the space provided for each part of each question. Answers must be written out in paragraph form. Outlines, bulleted lists, or diagrams alone are not acceptable and will not be scored. Friedreich's ataxia (<math alttext="F A" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>FA</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>) is an autosomal recessive genetic disorder that causes a lack of muscle control in patients. Heart defects are common in <math alttext="F A" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>FA</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> patients. <math alttext="F A" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>FA</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> is associated with a mutated <math alttext="F X N" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext mathvariant="italic">FXN</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> gene (<math alttext="lowercase f" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext mathvariant="italic">f</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> allele) that results in decreased levels of the mitochondrial protein frataxin, the <math alttext="F X N" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext mathvariant="italic">FXN</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> gene product. Muscle cells in individuals with <math alttext="F A" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>FA</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> produce decreased amounts of <math alttext="A T P" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>ATP</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> . The normal <math alttext="F X N" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext mathvariant="italic">FXN</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> gene contains several copies of a triplet of nucleotides in an intron. Mutant alleles of the gene have many more copies of the nucleotide triplet, which causes the <math alttext="F X N" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext mathvariant="italic">FXN</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> gene to be abnormally condensed. To investigate the effects of the <math alttext="F X N" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext mathvariant="italic">FXN</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> mutation, researchers studied heart cells from homozygous dominant individuals (<math alttext="uppercase F uppercase F" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext mathvariant="italic">FF</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>) without <math alttext="F A" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>FA</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> (genotype <math alttext="A" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>A</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>), heart cells from patients with <math alttext="F A" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>FA</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> (genotype <math alttext="B" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>B</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>), and heart cells from individuals heterozygous for the <math alttext="F X N" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext mathvariant="italic">FXN</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> gene (genotype <math alttext="C" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>C</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>). The researchers isolated two different proteins from an equal number of each of the three cell genotypes. For each cell genotype, they compared the amount of frataxin protein with the amount of glyceraldehyde <math alttext="3" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>3-</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>phosphate dehydrogenase (<math alttext="G A P D H" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>GAPDH</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>), an enzyme that functions in glycolysis (Figure 1). They then quantified the relative amount of frataxin protein in each cell genotype (Figure 2). Figure 1. Amounts of frataxin and <math alttext="G A P D H" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>GAPDH</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> proteins in the three different cell genotypes <math alttext="A" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>A</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>, <math alttext="B" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>B</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>, and <math alttext="C" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>C</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>, as revealed by band width following protein gel electrophoresis Figure 2. Quantified relative amount of frataxin protein in cell genotypes <math alttext="A" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>A</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>, <math alttext="B" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>B</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>, and <math alttext="C" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>C</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>. Data represent the average from six trials, as shown in Figure 1. Error bars represent <math alttext="plus or minus 2 S E sub x bar" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mo>±</mo><mn>2</mn><msub><mrow><mtext>SE</mtext></mrow><mrow><mover><mrow><mi>x</mi></mrow><mrow><mo>¯</mo></mrow></mover></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math>. To investigate a potential role for frataxin in cellular respiration, another group of researchers introduced the human <math alttext="F X N" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext mathvariant="italic">FXN</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> gene into a mouse cell line and overexpressed the frataxin protein. Identical control cells were similarly treated but did not receive the human <math alttext="F X N" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext mathvariant="italic">FXN</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> gene. The researchers measured the activity of a Krebs cycle enzyme in an equal number of control cells and cells overexpressing the human <math alttext="F X N" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext mathvariant="italic">FXN</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> gene (Figure 3). In a related experiment, an equal number of both cell types were grown in medium with <math alttext="C 14" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mmultiscripts><mrow><mtext>C</mtext></mrow><mprescripts></mprescripts><none></none><mrow><mn>14</mn></mrow></mmultiscripts><mtext>-</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>labelled glucose, and the researchers measured the amount of <math alttext="C 14" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mmultiscripts><mrow><mtext>C</mtext></mrow><mprescripts></mprescripts><none></none><mrow><mn>14</mn></mrow></mmultiscripts><mtext>-</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>labelled <math alttext="C O 2" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>CO</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math> produced by the cells (Figure 3). They also determined the concentration of lactic acid in both cell types (Figure 3). Figure 3. The activity of a Krebs cycle enzyme, the production of <math alttext="C 14" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mmultiscripts><mrow><mtext>C</mtext></mrow><mprescripts></mprescripts><none></none><mrow><mn>14</mn></mrow></mmultiscripts><mtext>-</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>labelled <math alttext="C O 2" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>CO</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math> after growth in a medium with <math alttext="C 14" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mmultiscripts><mrow><mtext>C</mtext></mrow><mprescripts></mprescripts><none></none><mrow><mn>14</mn></mrow></mmultiscripts><mtext>-</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>labelled glucose, and the concentration of lactic acid in control cells and in cells overexpressing the <math alttext="F X N" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext mathvariant="italic">FXN</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> gene. Values are shown relative to the values in the control cells. Error bars represent <math alttext="plus or minus 2 S E sub x bar" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mo>±</mo><mn>2</mn><msub><mrow><mtext>SE</mtext></mrow><mrow><mover><mrow><mi>x</mi></mrow><mrow><mo>¯</mo></mrow></mover></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math>. (a) Describe the possible genotypes of the heart cells of an individual if meiosis in this individual results in two sperm cells carrying the <math alttext="lowercase f" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext mathvariant="italic">f</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> allele and two sperm cells carrying the <math alttext="uppercase F" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext mathvariant="italic">F</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> allele.

frqParts.text: Read each question carefully. Write your response in the space provided for each part of each question. Answers must be written out in paragraph form. Outlines, bulleted lists, or diagrams alone are not acceptable and will not be scored. Friedreich's ataxia (<math alttext="F A" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>FA</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>) is an autosomal recessive genetic disorder that causes a lack of muscle control in patients. Heart defects are common in <math alttext="F A" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>FA</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> patients. <math alttext="F A" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>FA</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> is associated with a mutated <math alttext="F X N" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext mathvariant="italic">FXN</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> gene (<math alttext="lowercase f" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext mathvariant="italic">f</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> allele) that results in decreased levels of the mitochondrial protein frataxin, the <math alttext="F X N" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext mathvariant="italic">FXN</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> gene product. Muscle cells in individuals with <math alttext="F A" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>FA</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> produce decreased amounts of <math alttext="A T P" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>ATP</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> . The normal <math alttext="F X N" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext mathvariant="italic">FXN</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> gene contains several copies of a triplet of nucleotides in an intron. Mutant alleles of the gene have many more copies of the nucleotide triplet, which causes the <math alttext="F X N" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext mathvariant="italic">FXN</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> gene to be abnormally condensed. To investigate the effects of the <math alttext="F X N" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext mathvariant="italic">FXN</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> mutation, researchers studied heart cells from homozygous dominant individuals (<math alttext="uppercase F uppercase F" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext mathvariant="italic">FF</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>) without <math alttext="F A" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>FA</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> (genotype <math alttext="A" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>A</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>), heart cells from patients with <math alttext="F A" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>FA</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> (genotype <math alttext="B" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>B</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>), and heart cells from individuals heterozygous for the <math alttext="F X N" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext mathvariant="italic">FXN</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> gene (genotype <math alttext="C" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>C</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>). The researchers isolated two different proteins from an equal number of each of the three cell genotypes. For each cell genotype, they compared the amount of frataxin protein with the amount of glyceraldehyde <math alttext="3" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>3-</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>phosphate dehydrogenase (<math alttext="G A P D H" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>GAPDH</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>), an enzyme that functions in glycolysis (Figure 1). They then quantified the relative amount of frataxin protein in each cell genotype (Figure 2). Figure 1. Amounts of frataxin and <math alttext="G A P D H" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>GAPDH</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> proteins in the three different cell genotypes <math alttext="A" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>A</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>, <math alttext="B" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>B</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>, and <math alttext="C" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>C</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>, as revealed by band width following protein gel electrophoresis Figure 2. Quantified relative amount of frataxin protein in cell genotypes <math alttext="A" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>A</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>, <math alttext="B" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>B</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>, and <math alttext="C" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>C</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>. Data represent the average from six trials, as shown in Figure 1. Error bars represent <math alttext="plus or minus 2 S E sub x bar" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mo>±</mo><mn>2</mn><msub><mrow><mtext>SE</mtext></mrow><mrow><mover><mrow><mi>x</mi></mrow><mrow><mo>¯</mo></mrow></mover></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math>. To investigate a potential role for frataxin in cellular respiration, another group of researchers introduced the human <math alttext="F X N" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext mathvariant="italic">FXN</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> gene into a mouse cell line and overexpressed the frataxin protein. Identical control cells were similarly treated but did not receive the human <math alttext="F X N" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext mathvariant="italic">FXN</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> gene. The researchers measured the activity of a Krebs cycle enzyme in an equal number of control cells and cells overexpressing the human <math alttext="F X N" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext mathvariant="italic">FXN</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> gene (Figure 3). In a related experiment, an equal number of both cell types were grown in medium with <math alttext="C 14" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mmultiscripts><mrow><mtext>C</mtext></mrow><mprescripts></mprescripts><none></none><mrow><mn>14</mn></mrow></mmultiscripts><mtext>-</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>labelled glucose, and the researchers measured the amount of <math alttext="C 14" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mmultiscripts><mrow><mtext>C</mtext></mrow><mprescripts></mprescripts><none></none><mrow><mn>14</mn></mrow></mmultiscripts><mtext>-</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>labelled <math alttext="C O 2" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>CO</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math> produced by the cells (Figure 3). They also determined the concentration of lactic acid in both cell types (Figure 3). Figure 3. The activity of a Krebs cycle enzyme, the production of <math alttext="C 14" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mmultiscripts><mrow><mtext>C</mtext></mrow><mprescripts></mprescripts><none></none><mrow><mn>14</mn></mrow></mmultiscripts><mtext>-</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>labelled <math alttext="C O 2" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>CO</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math> after growth in a medium with <math alttext="C 14" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mmultiscripts><mrow><mtext>C</mtext></mrow><mprescripts></mprescripts><none></none><mrow><mn>14</mn></mrow></mmultiscripts><mtext>-</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>labelled glucose, and the concentration of lactic acid in control cells and in cells overexpressing the <math alttext="F X N" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext mathvariant="italic">FXN</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> gene. Values are shown relative to the values in the control cells. Error bars represent <math alttext="plus or minus 2 S E sub x bar" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mo>±</mo><mn>2</mn><msub><mrow><mtext>SE</mtext></mrow><mrow><mover><mrow><mi>x</mi></mrow><mrow><mo>¯</mo></mrow></mover></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math>. (a) Describe the possible genotypes of the heart cells of an individual if meiosis in this individual results in two sperm cells carrying the <math alttext="lowercase f" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext mathvariant="italic">f</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> allele and two sperm cells carrying the <math alttext="uppercase F" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext mathvariant="italic">F</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> allele.

(b) Identify a dependent variable for the experiment with data shown in Figure 2. Justify the measurement of <math alttext="C 14" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mtext></mtext><mrow><mmultiscripts><mrow><mtext>C</mtext></mrow><mprescripts></mprescripts><none></none><mrow><mn>14</mn></mrow></mmultiscripts><mtext>-</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>labelled <math alttext="C O 2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>CO</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math> in the experiment with data shown in Figure 3. Describe the difference between the mouse cells overexpressing the <math alttext="F X N" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext mathvariant="italic">FXN</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> gene and the control mouse cells with respect to the <math alttext="C 14" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mmultiscripts><mrow><mtext>C</mtext></mrow><mprescripts></mprescripts><none></none><mrow><mn>14</mn></mrow></mmultiscripts><mtext>-</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>labelled <math alttext="C O 2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>CO</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math> production shown in Figure 3. Based on the data in Figure 3, calculate how many times more lactic acid is produced on average in the control cells as compared with cells overexpressing <math alttext="F X N" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext mathvariant="italic">FXN</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>.

(c) Researchers produced mice that contained three copies of the <math alttext="F X N" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext mathvariant="italic">FXN</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> gene in each cell, producing genotype <math alttext="lowercase f lowercase f lowercase f" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext mathvariant="italic">fff</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>, rather than the typical two copies. Based on the data provided, predict the amount of frataxin protein most likely to be produced by the mice compared with the amount of frataxin in cells with genotypes <math alttext="A" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>A</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>, <math alttext="B" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>B</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>, and <math alttext="C" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>C</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>. Justify your prediction.

(d) Explain why the phenotypes associated with the human <math alttext="F X N" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext mathvariant="italic">FXN</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> gene can be studied in a mouse cell. Unlike skeletal muscle cells, heart muscle cells cannot rely on fermentation for long. Explain the inability of heart muscle cells to function using only fermentation for metabolism. <math alttext="A T P" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>ATP</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> acts as a negative feedback regulator of phosphofructokinase, one of the enzymes in glycolysis. Predict the eventual effect of <math alttext="A T P" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>ATP</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> on pyruvate production in heart cells that express excess amounts of the normal frataxin.
